												The Witcher series is known for its fantastic storytelling, interesting characters, and solid action, all of which have permeated not only the stories by Andrzej Sapkowski, but also the hugely popular video games developed by CD Projekt RED. The lore is strong, the characters are deep, and the land is lush. Now the Witcher universe has been tapped for board gaming. And in a strange, but intriguing, turn of events, the board game has been developed as a video game. Like any good adventure game, gameplay revolves around quests. In this case, each player has a distinct quest that they choose at the outset of the game. Each quest also has side-quests and goals that garner victory points. Depending on what length of game the players want, they will denote an amount of quests that need to be completed in order to trigger the end of the game. When the game ends, players will compare victory points and the player with the highest amount will win.The mechanics aren’t all that complicated, as the game mainly consists of traveling around a map and collecting clues that will turn into hard evidence and end up completing your quest upon arrival in a specific city. There is also a war track that essentially updates the monsters and obstacles in different regions. Die rolls determine victory among most challenges, with card buffs and special abilities that can modify the results. These die tests can spell the difference between taking down a prized beast and losing one of your abilities until you nurse your wounds via a rest action. Much of the gameplay is fairly reminiscent of Eldritch Horror, another Fantasy Flight game, and, unfortunately, this becomes a detriment to the Witcher theme and experience. I enjoy the mechanics of Eldritch Horror and can see how and why the designers would decide to incorporate elements of them into The Witcher, yet I feel like the implementation makes the game feel more like a checklist and less like a rousing adventure.Part of the problem lies in a misunderstanding of what makes The Witcher exciting. Take combat, for instance. I don’t think the unpredictability of die rolls makes for good Witcher battles. Geralt is wily, studious, strong, and knows a number of fighting techniques. However, in the game, it seems as if none of this matters, because it all comes down to rolling some dice and maybe playing a card or two, hoping that the battle goes well. Despite the fact that there are four characters, each with semi-distinct abilities and dice, it all feels characterless. I think this symptom stems from a very basic design misstep.The Witcher is very much a story-driven franchise that holds dear to plot development and character integrity, while weaving a tapestry of quests and events into the action. I don’t feel that weight and detail while playing this game. I feel as if the mechanics are meant to serve this notion, but they don’t cycle well together and everything feels like a series of other games that have been patched together in an attempt to make a cohesive design. There is no doubt that the game feels smooth and methodical; that there is a sense we are in a world of intrigue and danger. Yet, I couldn’t help but feel like the things I was doing didn’t really matter and the things my opponents were doing didn’t really matter and that we were all just playing semi-interactive solitaire, with a swingy vibe.I think what this game needed was a different identity from the outset, or perhaps a mechanic that took the main gameplay and made it more impactful and interesting. A campaign mode immediately comes to mind. Something which ebbs and flows and allows for a little more logic and strategy – studying monsters, utilizing specific combat strategies, and slaying them with a finer attention to unique qualities rather than hopefully getting a good combat card and some decent rolls. I really view this game as little more than a whirling dervish with very little player decision.The Witcher: Adventure game is a tough nut to crack. It’s not as if the elements to a great game aren’t there. It’s not as if there isn’t a somewhat compelling scheme. I found myself enjoying certain elements, such as seeking out the best path to completion of a quest. It’s just that everything is so distant feeling that there is difficulty being immersed and involved in the action. I suppose part of this is the natural outcome of playing a board game in a digital format, but nevertheless, I never quite felt the satisfaction of moving pieces around and developing a strategy or imagining an adventure the way I was probably supposed to.

												This game seems like a top-notch digital conversion of the boardgame, so if you enjoy the physical game and want an online copy, don't hesitate to buy this.  The price is right.TLDR: The game isn't terrible but also isn't great.  There's no meaningful interaction between the various players.  Constant status ailments can become frustrating.  3/5 stars.My negative review is of the game itself.  It's a simple four-player "collect various resources until you have the right combination to cash them in for victory points" type of game, coupled with basic dice-based combat (versus the environment, not versus the other players).  The main problem I have with this game is that there really isn't any interaction between the different players.  For example, I might draw a card that affects all of the players, but it happens automatically, whether I want it to or not.  At no time in the game was I able to choose to influence the other players in any way, either to help them or to hurt them.  So basically it boiled down to four players, each playing a single player game on the same board.  It wasn't terrible, but it wasn't very enjoyable either.  I originally bought the game in the hopes that multiplayer would be fun, but considering the lack of meaningful interaction, it kind of seems pointless now.And this game is dark.  You will be negatively afflicted with status ailments every freaking turn.  Because of this, the game becomes a long, grim slog to complete your quests.  This is all very true to the witcher universe, I just don't know that it lends itself toward making a game fun.On the plus side, the artwork is fantastic.  Having read the various Witcher stories and played the excellent RPGs allowed me to appreciate the lore that is depicted in this game.

												This is a simple but suprisingly entertaining game, made for fans of the Witcher series and who also enjoy casual board games. I'll start off by saying this: don't expect too much from this game; the system has been developed competently enough so that it offers more than an average amount of replayability, with gameplay duration lasting somewhere between 70-120mins depending on how many main quests are necessary to win the game - the number of quests to determine the victor can be chosen at the beginning of the game. However, if you are expecting the next X-Wing or Arkham Horror, you'd better look elsewhere. But if you can put such hype aside and play it for what it is: a decent board game that, if played with friends either online with this digital version, or face-to-face with the physical copy (the way I believe all board game SHOULD be played if you're able to do so) is worth your consideration. The Witcher Adventure Game is, in certain aspects, similar to Arkham Horror and Talisman - in fact to me it feels somewhat like a mish-mash of the two. Is it as good as Arkham Horror? In my opinion, no; Is it better than Talisman - if judging Talisman without all the expansions and basing the comparison simply on the base game itself - yes, to me at least it made for a more enjoyable experience, both online and face-to-face with the physical copy. In terms of gameplay; it's kind of a mish-mash of Arkham Horror and Talisman, so, like I said, this game has a level of spontaneity, with random spikes of difficulty throughout the game - but it makes for an interesting story as you're playing. Taking into consideration all the different events (foul events and good fortune), monsters (leveled as bronze - easy, silver - medium, and gold - hard) and the war track, it really isn't suprising how you might find yourself at the bottom of the pack if hit with too many unlucky cards a few turns in a row; but if you play it smart you generally defy the odds and hold out for these few 'bad' turns and bring yourself back into contention for first place. The characters are pretty well balanced. Having played with all but Triss, I've yet to find anything overpowering or game-breaking with any of the four playable characters. Each have their own pros and cons - not that I'll spoil their abilities; learning the playstyle of each character for the first time was half the fun! Last but now least, the artwork is pretty topnotch - and it should be, considering CDPR and FFG have sourced most of their material from the concepts done for the three witcher games. Overall I reckon it's worth a grab for witcher fans who also enjoy BOARD GAMES. This isn't a hard game to wrap your head around; you can learn the system within the first 10minutes; but it is enjoyable, and that, at least for me, makes it worth the buy.

												For an adaptation from a board game, this is a far cry from poor. The game's replay value is very high, and is a lot of fun to play with friends both locally and online. This game is very easy to learn, and introducing someone to the game is very quick, as short instructional videos are included in the game itself. If watching videos to learn isn't much your fancy, the game can be learned fairly easily through gameplay. The game successfully captures the darkness and the bad-to-worse story development of the Witcher literature and games, making the experience familiar and fulfilling to those familiar to the franchise while also fun to those who are not so familiar with the Witcher world. It also includes a feature allowing players to vary the length of the game by changing the number of requirements to be filled in order to achieve victory, making the game last anywhere between a twenty minute spree to a night-long affair depending upon what is desired.There are occasional bugs that crop up, such as results from dice rolls momentarily disappearing from the screen or development cards not glowing when they are usable, but such glitches are so few and far between that they do not hinder the experience much. The only other complaint worth mentioning about the game is that, to some, the experience may grow repetitive after successive playthroughs, as the gameplay is much the same from game to game. As such, many tend to take breaks in between playthroughs.I would rate this game an 8.5/10 for its fulfilling play yet repetitive nature.

												$3.15, an okay price for the game. This is an unfair review as I am slightly partial to CD Projekt Red's Witcher series. There are some flaws with the game design, such as multiplayer solitaire. I tried using Triss Merigold and she seemed fine. However, after playing multiple games, I've decided to vote it down, mainly due to the insane random events from dice rolling and card drawing.PROS1. Follows the Witcher SeriesVery accurate, all the main characters are inside. I was actually looking forward to using the Scoia'tael (Elves), Philippa Eilhart (Mage ♥♥♥♥♥) or Saskia (Dragoness) in the game.2. IntuitiveIt's easy to learn. I didn't play a single tutorial to be able to understand the game.CONS1. Multiplayer Solitaire *****You don't really care about any other player as none of actions matter to you. There is hardly any player interaction.2. Advanced Snakes and Ladders *****It is just personal racing like advanced Snakes and Ladders. You just roll dice and play the game on your own. 3. Random Monsters and CombatThis is so boring. The random monster generation doesn't capture the fantastic monsters that I experienced playing the Witcher 2. To defeat SINGLE monsters, you roll Swords and Shields. If you roll a sufficient amount of Swords, you kill the monster. If you roll a sufficient amount of Shields, you block its negative effect. It lacks the skilled planning and excitement that the normal Witcher game brings since it all boils down to Sword and Shield. 4. Random Bad Fortune and Investigation CardsSome just make you lose 2 VP just for drawing them and some just do nothing. The randomness is horrendous. The investigation cards are also full of negative cards called Setbacks which have no redeeming value. If you draw badly, you are screwed.SUGGESTIONS1. TrapsIf you arrive in a location, you can play a card that leaves a surprise for the next player who crosses (not land) its path. It might be a nasty surprise or a simple challenge. That way players will look at where other players are moving to.2. Learning Other Player's AbilitiesCurrently, each player has their own unique development deck. No one will care about what another player develops.Based on the abolve design, one deck will likely be superior to the others. It would be interesting to take 2-3 developments that belong to other players as your own. This could create crazy combos and make player's more interested in what the others are doing.3. Global QuestsThis will give something that everyone will fight over for VP. E.g. Save Ciri. Pay 3 Blue Leads, 3 Purple Leads and 3 Red Leads for 12 VP. Only completable once.

												For a digitized board game, The Witcher Adventure Game is pretty fun. It's a great mix of strategy and luck where you will essentially battle the game itself more than the opposing players. The object of the game is to complete objectives in as few turns as possible to collect Victory Points. Whoever has the most VP at the end of the game wins.The mechanics of the game are handled well. Battles, random events, and consequences of cards make the game tense without making it a chore. My only complaints are 1) that the computer AI is too easy overall, often seeming clueless as to what they should be doing and falling behind rapidly and 2) AI opponent turns can take forever (wait-fest). Since both of my complaints are leveled at AI opponents, you can avoid these hassles by having friends. Otherewise, 1v1 with an AI opponent is not too bad.

Every turn there is likely to be a combat, and many of the combats give VP... because of this, it is possible for the combat characters (really just Geralt, because he's the best fighter) to lap all adversaries on VP even if he doesn't come CLOSE to finishing as many quests. This game is like going to a dance contest and realizing you're also going to be judged on your attire, which is okay I guess BUT WAIT... you're ALSO going to be judged on a juggling routine... and somebody else is an expert juggler. 												The Witcher Adventure Game is a fun little digital board game which has a resemblance to Elder Sign.While it may look difficult and at the start also feel difficult, it's easy to learn and once you get into it you barely feel the difficulty any longer.The game has a multiplayer mode. Although it needs a lot of work.The multiplayer mode lacks a lot of key features you would connect with multiplayer. For instance, you cannot start a public multiplayer game and then invite your friends. This is a huge minus. Same goes for creating a private game. There is no way to create a private and invite a friend and then open it up to the public. So playing with friends abroad is often a challenge just to get the game started.It's a very interactive game in terms of collecting items, quests and spells and spending gold. Along the way you will face obstacles, evil monsters and other nasty things out for blood. These can at times be a little challenging and make it feel like you're being set back a little. As the game progresses, you will become stronger and stronger.The game is based around questing. Currently you can pick between doing 1, 3 or 5 quests in order to finish the game. Who ever has the most Victory Points (VP) at the end wins.The game lacks character player interacting. With the extreme weak AI it is often more beneficial to play against or with other real people, but even so it still feel like you're playing against the a slightly stronger version of the AI. It lacks some interaction elements with other players instead of an action tab where you can see their roles. While you get to see what monster they're fighting, you don't get to see the monsters strenght and benefits. This makes it a little tedious and most players just sit around and wait for their turn without really having to pay attention to what the other 1-3 players are doing.The community is a little dead and it can sometimes take a while to find other players.There's a HUGE lack of information on the forums in terms of what direction the game is going to such an extant that there's not even any sticky posts from the developers. It makes the game feel dead and when I take a look at other digital board games forums (on steam) their forums usually thrives of activity.The 4 classes you can pick between are all different in terms of play style, which is a great thing. Downside is, there's just these 4 and there are no news about them adding more.As much as I want to recommend this game to people I just simply can't.It feels dead and tedious to play and I regret not only buying a copy for myself but also gifted a copy to a friend before I knew what hassle the multiplayer would be. Along we're having random disconnect issues to deal with as well, which is not making all the bad things look any better.This is a game that you can acquire on most platforms but without cross platform, it should probably just have stayed on tablets.

												Not that great of a board game unfortunately. I like long adventure board games (such as Runebound and World Of Warcraft the Boardgame) and this was just kind of boring. Half way through the game I was just wanting the game to end and when it finally did end all I did was look to the ceiling and sigh heavily saying, "finally!".Some issues I specifically had:-Tutorial, it has you watch the first tutorial and that is all it tells you, next thing the game asks is if you want to play offline or online. Turns out there is like a dozen more tutorial videos in the main screen's menu though I didn't know that as it doesn't really make it easy to know.--At least the rule book you can access in game isn't that bad.-You can't tell what is going on in opponents turn. AI opponents take their turn really quickly with cards and effects happening all over the place but it still takes the 3 of them at least a minute to get through their turns, So the game might as well be single player game with 1-2 minute lag between turns because that is what it amounted to. What the opponents were doing didn't really matter other than the automated "bad stuff" that happens to you on the beginning of your turn from their Foul Fates and you don't have to pay attention for any--The activity log always being up on their turns would help, the monster that an opponent is fighting always being up on the left side of the battle screens would help too to know what is going on and what just happened to them. Especially on the battle results screen so I don't have to specifically try and remember what his negative effects for losing were.-SO MUCH bad stuff happening to you every turn, feels like you have no control over it because so much happens every turn.--It actually got to a point in my game where I had something like 10 turns where I was stuck unable to do anything but rest every turn from all the bad stuff I was suffering every single turn. Foul fates laying down more foul fates, wounds, deadly wounds. Foul fates from other players constantly. Monsters that have bad effects from just fighting them (more foul fates and wounds). More monsters spawning. On and on and on.-----90% of every turn was dealing with bad stuff happening from foul fates or other player's foul fates.-A few little glitchy spots where music cut out for a few minutes and sometimes the game wouldn't detect I had something I could do, had to restart the game once since it literally wouldn't let me take an action. And several times where I had a witcher sign but the game didn't think so then all of a sudden 30 seconds later it would say "oh, you do have one, ok you can use it now".-AI are really dumb at times, I'd see them use a spell/card that gives them more defense dice...then not use the dice and somehow fail the combat's defence section. Rather often too. I won my game but it took over 2 hours for a game that the main screen said should be 45 minutes, some of that may have been me not knowing how to best play but man is that a difference.Wouldn't recommend the game. Maybe I just had a really bad first game but it certainly wasn't no 45 minutes long 3-quest game. Second half of the game really felt like it was dragging on. And the game didn't feel much like an adventure game, you don't really power up your characer other than from development cards and those you can just get every turn without doing anything (literally the only way to get them is using an action to draw 2 keep 1), no gear from quests or looting monsters, no new powers really from leveling up type of stuff. Just spam development cards to get what powers you want then move around trying to collect a dozen investigation tokens of certain colors and hope the piles of bad stuff happening to you ever turn doesn't hinder you tooo much.And hey, I only played a single-player vs 3 AI game, maybe when playing multiplayer with actual other people it will get better. Though I worry about downtimes greatly increasing in that case.

												Edited 5/8/15: So, even with the rise in players due to the witcher sale i'm having an extremely hard time joining any online games. As a result of the dying/dead online community, i'm going to change the review to a not reccomend. It's still a fun board game and you CAN local co-op the game but is the solo experience worth 10 bucks? I'd say no when there are other options. I also looked at the steam charts and while the player-base has risen to 200 players, i'm still having trouble finding games. If you have friends to play with, this game may be worth the money. otherwise i advise saving the money for something else.so i just played a match against the AI as Triss and here's my detailed-revew-after-1-game for those of you that have that feeling that you just can't wait to play the game but are worried about the game being some sort of con.TL:DRThis is a fun board game and anyone that likes board games should probably pick this up and support it.The actual explaination of the game in my experience during 1 round, since the info given is kinda bare-bonesThis board game involves you playing as 1 of four characters and completing various objectives on a quest card to score points. The objectives often are either:1. go to some area and spend resources to get points2. Just go to some area and you get points3. just spend resources and get points4. go to another person and spend resources to assist them with THEIR quest and get points while they get half as many pointsIt's simple enough but what makes it difficult is the board itself and two kinds of setbacks.the first setback is drawing a misfortune card. There are 3 ways to get misfortune cards.1. An effect of another card/monster2. fast travel (moveing 2 spaces for the price of 1!!!)3, move to a space and be forced to draw a misfortune card.The misfortune cards have various effects from getting hurt, monsters and bad guys spontaneously spawning out of your rear to paying some sort of toll or even choosing between the last two options as I never really encountered the first with either of the other two.The second setback is monster cards. Monster cards are ranked from bronze, to silver, to gold, each with increasing lethality each time. Monster cards can have various, previously mentioned effects as well, but they mostly just injure you. When you're injured you're incapable of using the action that's injured until it's healed. Some cards can heal you or you can heal yourself for the cost of one of your 2 actions. some monsters can make a quest much harder to deal with, with an example being a troll that kicked the AI's butt and I conciously avoided until i got strong enough to deal with it. You fight monsters by rolling a hero die, and a number of regular dice. the hero die tends to resonate with your development cards (next paragraph) while the regular dice have either a defense, an attack, or a blank face. meet the required amount of attacks or defenses and you succeed in either attacking or defending. attacking a monster successfully takes it off the board and can possibly yeild rewards while defending averts a bad effect from taking place. Monsters need to be killed in a single roll, their damage does not stay on between turns.Speaking of getting stronger, you do so by drawing development cards. Development cards have various effects as well, in my case they alll had to do with rolling a hero die just right during combat, (i didn't encounter any development cards that ouright added the number of dice i roll or anything). you can choose, for an action, to draw 2 development cards and keep 1. Some development cards are much stronger than others and their effects seem to vary, (though as triss i only drew development cards that aided me in combat, which was lucky for me in this case, but each character has their own development cards by my understanding, though i think other characters CAN use other character's development cards. I'll edit this later if i'm wrong). Development cards need to be charged before they can be used and you can put a charge on a development card by using an action to charge it.You cannot use the same action twice on one turn.Finally i'll touch on resource gathering. you gather things called clues which come in the colors of blue, purple, and red. you get clues by either:1. moving to an area and drawing 1 clue of one of the colors on the area2. investigating for an action and drawin 1 clue of 1 of the three colors3. getting cards which boost the number of clues you get. These cards tend to happen when drawing clues and can sometimes have negative effects but often have traits which resonnate with other traits and get you lots of clues in 1 go, if you're lucky enough.There's also some war tick thing that never came into play when i used it either that or i didn't notice its effect... sooo i guess i'm lucky.I don't think i missed anything, so i'll now move on to the impression the game gave me.I enjoyed the game. somewhere along the line the whole thing started feeling very natural to me and i started making strategic decisions on where to go, which rout i should take to get to a destination, and what actions i can afford to spare preparing myself for what's to come and which actions i needed to use to collect resources or get the hell out of rivia (where the freaking harpy just landed!) Overall it's a very fun game and if you're a fan of board games i think you should get it. it's only about a day old so i haven't found a multiplayer match yet but I dabbled in the multiplayer options and i found a small chatbox on the top left of the screen, which is vital for games like this where playing the player can be just as important as playing the game.The downside to this game that i can see so far is that the tutorial consists of a bunch of videos as opposed to a hands-on experience, so that may make it just a little annoying for some people to get into it but i found that once i started playing i eventually got the hang of it.Also the visuals aren't too impressive. it's really just a board with pieces on it and some music in the background which actually bugged out on me once and just stopped. it didnt hinder the game at all, it was just less musical.I could give some arbitrary numerical score but overall i reccommend it and i definately hope a community grows around it so it can see further development.arbitrary score:pi x the square root of negative x where x is the number of sex cards available in the first game / something of slightly higher value... like actually getting laid.... dang this revew ran long, hope it was helpful...

												As far as a digital implementation of a board game, this is fairly good. It's a nice PC interface. Everything works fairly well. (The dice are a little funky, but eh... whatever).I love the Witcher series. I was excited when this game was announced. I was excited to see this game hit the store.If you you love The Witcher Adventure Game, and want a digital implementation, then stop reading and just buy it.If you haven't played The Witcher Adventure Game, let me stop you right there and say "Don't". Go buy Merchants of Venus, Xia: Legend of a Drift System, Steam, Merchants & Marauders, Istanbul, or even Firefly: The Game. Those are all vastly superior Pick-Up and Deliver games - which is all this is. An unnessessarily complicated, frustrating, painful, lengthy Pick-Up and Deliver game.It's a mean game. And I don't mean that in the way that Diplomacy or even Munchkin is a "mean game". Or even how "Ghost Stories is brutally difficult". I mean this game stabs you in the liver, and then deducts points from you because you're bleeding like a wimp.The designer is a wonderful designer. He also owns the game publisher "Portal Games". Go check out all of his other games (Robinson Crusoe, Imperial Settlers, 51st State, The New Era, Pret-a-Porter). This doesn't even measure up to the worst game I've played from Fantasy Flight.The interaction between players is awful. It's mostly a solitare experience. Which doesn't help when the game points how you don't have any friends.The turns are very repetative. Especially when the game finally gets you into the fetal position, and all it leaves you to do is to rock back and forth as you bleed from your severed ankles.Ever played Bunco? Where you just roll the dice, hoping to roll three of a kind? No agency. No decision making. Just luck of the RNG. This game wants you to roll a 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, or 10 of a kind with 3-4 dice - and that's not really an exaggeration. When when you fail, because - well - math, you take damage.Nothing good really happens to you. And when it does, like finally completing one of your quests, you STILL get punished. For a good ol' fashioned "Good job. ♥♥♥♥ you." - like mom use to say.The monsters seem incredibly out of balance. Rolling the dice usually seems like a wasted effort. There ARE things you HAVE to get in order to over come the dice, but those dont' seem well balanced either.This is easily one of the worst board game experiences I've had in the last few years.The only value this game has had for me is that I only spent $8 on this before foolishly spending $60 at my local game store. And for that, I'll look very favorably at it.10/10.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Where to begin? The game does an excellent job of creating the theme to The Witcher games. Characters, environments and monsters all give it that excellent feel that the games have. Detailed and impressive art work can be found from it's map to the monster cards. It has the look and feel of an actual board game.I've invested a few hours of the game and have played a few of the "Complete 3 Quests" games. The pacing of the game is alright, though a bit of downtime between turns towards the late game. Be prepared to do something in the background while you wait your turn. A signal to anounce that your turn has come would be very helpful. One major complaint I have with this game is it seems you are penialized for doing practically everything. I understand that the universe of The Witcher is a very unforgiving thing, but having to draw a fate card for almost every action (while having a fate token on an action) seems excessive. Most games I have played I have spent either trying to remove Fate tokens from my actions, or healing from wounds. I don't know if this is a major part of the game, dealing with Fate tokens, but it became more of an annoyance. The quest system works well. Having to do investigations to gain resources works well and having side quests helps along the way to acheieving your quests. Side quests can give a bit more flavour to the game and is a great way to earn some extra Victory Points. The battle system is alright, though it reminds me more of Elder Sign than anything else. Roll dice, match symbols, if you have enough, you win! If you don't! Bad stuff happens (if you don't defend).The game has a lack of save system, which I find odd. So if you're wanting to play a long game but don't have the time to invest, prepare to be disapointed or to have the game run in the background. For me, the game does a very good job of emulating a board game, but the mechanics are either ones I've played from other games, and does much better or just flat out annoy me for existing. I cannot really recommend this game.

												Essentially, this is a board game RPG based on The Witcher series of games, utilizing cards and dice to determine outcomes.  The implementation is fairly simple to understand, particularly since you can play a game without any opponents.  This allows one to get a feel for the game goals, mechanics, and character abilities.  Overall, it is a fairly simple game, but for the price, is a unique game implementation.Playing against the AI tends to get old quickly, but this is a great game to play with one's children if one is an older gamer with children such as myself.  The rules are relatively easy to understand, and the implementation of cards can be a useful tool to help children with their reading abilities.  The game encourages them to think ahead, and consider the probable outcomes.  Playing alone gets old, but given the price and nature of the game, I highly recommend it as a "family game" to play with the kids.

												I should mention that I also have the physical board game and have played it with friends.As a singleplayer experience, this is a decent game. It's meant to be role-played, you have to read the quests to feel any kind of depth. The formula is actually very close to the actual Witcher games: you have a main quest and some side quests. As you try to finish the main quest you get sidetracked with tasks and character development and do other things. Being a computer game, you don't have to keep track of the game rules that much, the game does it for you, so you have more time to concentrate on the fights and quests.As a multiplayer experience I feel that it's not that fun, though. There is very little player interaction, so there's no point in it being a multiplayer experience really. You might as well play alone without even any AI players.Some of the mechanics could have been improved, there are no keyboard shortcuts, which prevents effective Steam Controller use (mouse only).But overall I think it's a quaint little game, Witcher fans will enjoy it.
